evidence_span: The quantitites of methanol required to initiate cracking (Table 4) in $\mathbf { C C l } _ { 4 } / \mathbf { l } _ { 2 }$ solutions were much greater than that required for equivalence with the iodine in a molecular complex.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: FIG. 4—Almost completely intergranular failure in ethylene glycol/iodine solutions. A few transgranular features are visible in b.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: FIG. 5—Boundary between intergranular (a, top) and ductile (a, bottom) fracture for a specimen removed from methanol/iodine solution at the first cracking sound (monitored by acoustic emission) and broken immediately in air at room temperature
process_step: broken in air at room temperature

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: FIG. 6Boundary between intergranular (a, top) and ductile (a, bottom) fracture for a specimen removed from methanol/iodine solution at the first acoustic emission signal; annealed in vacuum for three days at $3 0 \time 1 0 ^ { \circ } C ,$ and broken in air at room temperature
process_step: annealed in vacuum for three days at 300°C, broken in air at room temperature

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: Attempts to repeat these experiments on Zircaloy-2 specimens were unsuccessful. No differences were found in fractography between annealed and unannealed specimens which were partially cracked in methanol/iodine and then broken in air (Figs. 5 and 6).

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: Additions of sodium arsenite to methanol/ iodine solutions resulted in a large increase in time to failure (Table 4)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: Arsenate additions had no effect on times to failure and produced no reaction with the solution and no deposits.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: Table 3 shows that times to failure rise dramatically at iodine concentrations below 0.01 percent.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: The effects of saturating the solution with $\mathbf { N } _ { 2 } \mathbf { O }$ (Table 3) give further evidence that transient species play an important part in processes at the crack tip.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk4
evidence_span: Only under conditions where iodine is released within the crack does the specimen crack in aqueous Nal. Release of iodine from an adjacent electrode, even after initiation by polarizing the stressed specimen, was insufficient to permit continued crack growth.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: cracking of Zircaloy-2 in alcoholic/iodine solutions

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: Cracking is initiated by an intergranular dissolution process in these solutions

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: changes to a rapid transgranular propagation process

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: the amount of transgranular propagation present decreases as the intergranular dissolution rate decreases

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: cracks are always transgranular in these specimens

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: saturating the methanol/iodine solution with N2O causes only a small effect on the crack propagation velocity in DCB specimens

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: the crack propagation time is only a very small fraction of the total time to failure

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: Examination of pre-transition films formed on Zircaloy-4 oxidized in 360°C water revealed a small grain size of approximately 100 Å (10 nm) diameter

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: at the oxide-water surface (oldest oxide), a grain size of less than 50 Å (5 nm) was observed

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: at the metal-oxide surface (newest oxide), the grain size was approximately 200 Å (20 nm)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: In post-transition films the outermost oxide still possessed the very fine 50 Å (5 nm) diameter grain size

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: the newest oxide of post-transition films consisted of relatively large grains, with grain diameters of 1000 to 5000 Å (100 to 500 nm)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: Pore sizes ranged from approximately 10 to 150 Å (1 to 15 nm)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: Under more severe oxidizing conditions, imposed by increasing the corrosion temperature to 427°C (800°F), the growth of large grains at the metal-oxide interface was unstable and film growth proceeded by the nucleation of finer grains

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: the bulk of the post-transition oxide film is of nonprotective character as is obvious from the connected pore networks

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_034_chunk6
evidence_span: Grain growth proceeds until a limiting size of 2000 to 5000 Å (200 to 500 nm) is reached
